Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: ABI Innovation: Genome-Wide Inference of mRNA Isoforms and Abundance Estimation from Biased RNA-Seq Reads
Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of California, Riverside and University of California, Los Angeles are awarded collaborative grants to identify mRNA isoforms on a genome-wide basis. Due to alternative splicing events in eukaryotic cells, the identification of mRNA isoforms (or transcripts) is a difficult problem in molecular biology. Traditional experimental methods for this purpose are time-consuming and cost ineffective. The emerging RNA-Seq technology provides a possible effective way to address this problem. This project aims to develop efficient and accurate methods for inferring isoforms and estimating their abundance levels from RNA-Seq data where the reads may be sampled non-uniformly due to the existence of various biases including positional, sequencing and mappability biases. In particular, a novel statistical framework based on quasi-multinomial distributions will be introduced and a companion expectation-maximization (EM) algorithm developed for estimating isoform abundance levels that can handle all above biases in RNA-Seq data. The algorithms will be implemented efficiently in C++, tested extensively on both simulated and real RNA-Seq data in human, mouse and drosophila, and made available to the public for free. The performance of the algorithms will be evaluated extensively using both simulated and real RNA-Seq data. In the latter case, perturbations to some important splicing factors will be introduced into selected cell lines to induce widespread alteration of splicing events. RNA-Seq data of these cells, combined with quantitative RT-PCR validation, will provide an enriched dataset to assess the performance of the algorithms in predicting both isoform abundance and relative variation. In addition, the validation results may provide insight on the regulatory functions of the splicing factors and serve as a testbed for further improvement of the algorithms.

The broader impact of this project is twofold. First, RNA-Seq data analysis is a timely topic in bioinformatics due to the recent rapid advance in next generation sequencing (NGS) technologies and its potential impact in life sciences and medicine. Despite the success of many RNA-Seq applications, several challenges remain in the analysis of RNA-Seq data, one of which comes from the understanding and handling of biases in RNA-Seq reads. The approaches proposed in this project for treating RNA-Seq biases combine unique techniques from statistics, machine learning and combinatorial algorithms. Moreover, the experimental validation results may shed light on the regulatory functions of some important splicing factors. Second, the project will provide an excellent opportunity for the training of two computer science PhD students, a postdoc and two biology undergraduate students in the interdisciplinary field of computational biology and bioinformatics. Since many of the involved students are female, the research will also help improve the representation of women in science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this NSF project, the PI and his graduate students and collaborators conducted research on several fundamental problems concerning the analysis of high throughput sequencing data, including RNA-Seq data, Hi-C data and metagenomic data. Their special interest is in the correction of systematic biases in these data and understanding how the correction would help improve the inference and quantification of mRNA isoforms (or transcripts), alternative polydenylation sites and other splicing singatures, differential expression analysis and the determination of chromosomal structures.

Their work on the prediction of alternative polyadenylation sites of isoforms from RNA-Seq data will likely result in more accurate annotations of isoforms in the transcriptomics practice since most existing transcriptome assembly tools including Cufflinks and StringTie are unable to estimate the external boundaries of isoforms accurately. Their work on alignment-free estimation of exon inclusion ratios (or PSI values) provides the first accurate method for performing alternative splicing analysis for organisms that do not yet have good transcriptomic annotations.  Their work on a novel combinatorial approach for transcriptome assembly reveals interesting applications of well-known graph and combinatorial optimization problems (such as path cover and bin-packing) in RNA-Seq data analysis. It is hopeful that this will generate new perspectives on transcriptome assembly, which is an inherently difficult combinatorial problem, and attract more interest from the combinatorial optimization community. Their work on differential gene expression analysis provides an interesting example where a probabilistic model (i.e., Markov random field) can be solved by a well-known combinatorial optimization technique (i.e., maximum network flow). This is interesting because probabilistic models are widely adopted in bioinformatics and in many cases, the models are solved by heuristic methods due to time constraint. Many researchers believe that a careful combination of statistics and combinatorial optimization might produce more effective solutions. Hence, this work may inspire more successful applications of clever combinatorial optimization techniques in solving probabilistic models in bioinformatics. The work from the project has resulted in multiple publications in leading bioinformatics and genomics journals such as Bioinformatics, Genome Biology, Nucleic Acids Research, Cell Systems, and BMC Genomics, and top bioinformatics conferences including RECOMB and ISMB, as well as many software tools that have been made available to the public for free. In particular, the results concerning the inference and quantification of isoforms and sensitive differential expression analysis received the Best Paper Award at the 13th Asia Pacific Bioinformatics Conference (APBC'2017) and coverage in popular scientific news media Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News.

The project has also provided training opportunies for five Ph.D students and two MSc students in the Department of Computer Science and Engineering at UC Riverside, including two female students. Except for one student, the students had no prior experience in genomics or bioinformatics. Through the research work, they learned how to understand and process real biological (sequencing) data, how to interact with biologists and understand their needs, and how to make their work/tools more relevant to biological practice. The research topics and results generated from the project have also been used to enhance classroom teaching at both the graduate and undergraduate levels.
